generif.text: Protein levels of Prx-I and Prx-II were significantly increased in Alzheimer Disease and Down Syndrome.

2-Cys Prxs act in a mutually nonredundant and sometimes stress-specific fashion to protect human cells from oxidant injury. The substantial resistance of human cells to hydroperoxides may result in part from the additive action of multiple Prxs
Data show that peroxiredoxin I (Prx I)activity decreased gradually during catalysis, coincident with the conversion of Prx I to a more acidic species.
No detectable changes in expression of peroxiredoxin 1 are observed in postmortem cerebellum or frontal cortex of patients with Down syndrome, Alzheimer or Pick's disease.
results show that the sulfinic form of peroxiredoxin I, produced during the exposure of cells to H2O2, is rapidly reduced to the catalytically active thiol form

a crucial difference between PRDX1 and PRDX2 is on the resolution step of the catalytic cycle, the rate of disulfide formation (11 s(-1) for PRDX1, 0.2 s(-1) for PRDX2, independent of the oxidant) which correlates with their different sensitivity to hyperoxidation.

BP.term: regulation of non-canonical NF-kappaB signal transduction

interpro.desc: Alkyl hydroperoxide reductase subunit C/ Thiol specific antioxidant

name: peroxiredoxin 1

reactome.name: Deregulated CDK5 triggers multiple neurodegenerative pathways in Alzheimer's disease models

summary: This gene encodes a member of the peroxiredoxin family of antioxidant enzymes, which reduce hydrogen peroxide and alkyl hydroperoxides. The encoded protein may play an antioxidant protective role in cells, and may contribute to the antiviral activity of CD8(+) T-cells. This protein may have a proliferative effect and play a role in cancer development or progression. Four transcript variants encoding the same protein have been identified for this gene. [provided by RefSeq, Jan 2011].
